div.p: 1. (ET: tōḻi) itu talaimakaṟkuc (EN, ER, ET: talaimakaṭkuc) colliyatu. 2. talaimakaṉ vantoḻukavum vēṟupāṭu kaṇṭāḷ “avaṉ varuvaṉ ākavu nī vēṟupaṭṭāy veṟi eṭuttuk koḷḷum vakaiyāṉ” eṉṟatūumām.

1. This is what is said to HIM. 2. It is also how she who saw the changes when HE kept coming said “even though he come you have undergone changes, because of the wayin which the Veṟi [dance] has been set up.”

lg.l: to the man from a land, where fragrant honeycombs are oozing,

made within the limit of houses as if one saw a picture(?),This whole line is rather enigmatic. Is this supposed to refer to bee husbandry? Or does il here refer to the single honey comb which contains the honey? And is the beehive itself a picturesque sight? with
the sky flowers of the fertile soil from the black-trunked Kuṟiñci
on the rich long hills on which great rain have poured

so that the water increases in the springs of fearful vast areacūruṭai might refer to evil spirits roaming about, and naṉantalai might either mean a large mountain spring or the surroundings as such.,

[he has] no love for us.”kātalam aṉmai: this is one of the typically under-marked main sentences, literally meaning no more than "absence of love". The kātalam can either be read as a 1.pl. (which would have to be interpreted as "absence of us being loved") or as an even more elliptical adjective formation.

since the spear-bearing [priest] has been broughttaṇṭu probably refers here to the usual sequence of events, that is, the mother having brought in the priest. T.V.G., however, suggests to read it as a causal instrumental here: because of the Vēlaṉ.,
the courtyard strewn with sand having taken scent.
